column4: I m on this journey to change my eating habits  and one thing I really enjoy is a bit of asparagus. So I dropped into your Redditch store this evening  having recently converted to Sainsbury s because in our town your fruit and veg selection is of a higher quality than your competitors. I was pleased to grab some Strawberries that had come from Staffordshire.  But then I got to the asparagus.  I was really looking forward to getting hold of some big thick asparagus spears at a good price because of them being in season and being grown only 20 miles south of your store in Evesham.  The BBC website says:  More asparagus is grown in Worcestershire than anywhere else in the UK  and the asparagus from the Vale of Evesham has been considered the best in the world for many years.   But instead I was greeted with a packet of thin-looking spears that had come all the way from Peru. I ve been on Google Maps  Sainsbury s  and it tells me that s around 6 026 miles away from the Redditch store - and that s as the crow flies. Let s not get into the financial and environmental cost of transporting the goods.   How can it be that you can get Strawberries from Staffordshire to your Redditch store when that county is some 60 miles away on the other side of Birmingham  and yet you can t get asparagus into the store when it s only 20 miles south?
column9: Hi there Mike, the UK weather in March and April was unusually cold. This delayed the UK crop. We have in the past been 100% British as early as April 15th, and as late as May 23rd. We have been selling indoor grown British asparagus since March, but the weather is the driver for when we can get our outdoor crops, and so this year it's late. Debs

column4: Very frustrated!  I made an order 2 weeks ago for delivery and they gave me a coupon saying if I spent 50 pounds I would save 10.  So I made a point to order this week in time to use said coupon.  I ordered 53 pounds worth of items just to be sure I could use it. Now when it is delivered said coupon does not show up!!  So within 5 minutes of the delivery man coming I ring up the number on my receipt to make a complaint.   I do not agree with the charges.   I am told there is NOTHING they can do!  I must have made an error on my end.  Well I certainly use the computer all the time and am fairly certain I DID put in said code but either way I am now stuck having to take this food back to my local Sainsburys to return it on the sheer principal!!!  I would not have ordered the 50 pounds worth without having saved the 10 pounds!!!  It is far better to shop in store if this is the type of service you are offering on delivery!  I told the man on the phone I was going to complain and he was not the least bit bothered.  Well I assure you I AM!!!
column9: It is annoying as I would have turned away the order if I had seen the receipt total before the chap left.  I rang immediately when I saw it :(

column4: I am concerned that pricing in stores can be misleading.  This evening I picked up some Sainsburys salmon from the shelf  rather than the fish counter and looking at the shelf thought that it was £2.50.  This seemed like a good deal and this influenced my choice of product.  However  at the till this actually rang up as £5.00.  The explanation was that it was two portions of fish each at £2.50.  This seems reasonable  but in that case why is it priced on the shelf at £2.50!  All of the packages seemed to contain 2 pieces of fish.  Technically I am sure that it makes it clear on the shelf that it is per portion and on the packaging itself it says £2.50 on one side and then £5 on the other  but this is misleading and with all the controversy around packaging changes and alterations to weights I feel that it might well be intentional.  You might say this is only £2.50 and it won t break the bank  but none-the-less  I am cross about this.  Please do something about this Sainsburys  you can do better than this.   On the upside your staff were very helpful  despite not being able to offer a resolution.
column9: I'm sorry about that David. Can you send us a pic of the barcode from the product and confirm which branch you were in? I would be happy to look into this further. Grant

column4: Dear Mr Sainsbury   I often shop in one of your many stores nationwide and yet I feel am forced to comment on how annoying your self checkout is  and how easily it could be fixed with a simple changes to the settings.  As a conscientious citizen  I always try to make use of my backpack for my groceries rather than taking a harmful  potentially world ending plastic monstrosity (despite most of my fresh produce being wrapped in plastic too  but I ll save that for another letter).  After selecting from your wares and approaching the checkout  I am usually invited by staff to use the  self checkout  even though in my reality there appears to be no such thing. The fine persons are bewildered by my hesitance  but I am fully aware of the approaching inevitability.  I approach the synthetic human  and am presented with the option...  I have my own bag   which I dutifully select. I am then invited to place said bag(s) upon the weighing contraption  which I again dutifully complete and tell the synthetic human I am finished.  My ears are then filled with those piercing words...  please wait while we verify your bags . And I do. The real humans are busy serving other customers  refilling the shelves with fine wares  or collaborating and deliberating on who in Britain really does have talent. The synthetic human is patiently waiting for some form of consent from their human masters to proceed. My fellow customers appear to look upon me with some malcontent  for they too are awaiting the purchase of goods such that they may return to their loved ones and prepare sustenance.  Eventually a real human appears and I can continue with my purchase  until such time as an  unexpected item  appears in the bagging area  despite this item being the bag which I tried so hard to introduce to the synthetic mere moments ago.  In summary  please  for the sake of all humanity  change the setting and allow our own bags to be automatically authorised by our faithful synthetic humans.  Thanking you in anticipation
column9: Very clever, made me chuckle :)

I have my own bag   which I dutifully select. I am then invited to place said bag(s) upon the weighing contraption  which I again dutifully complete and tell the synthetic human I am finished.  My ears are then filled with those piercing words...  please wait while we verify your bags . And I do. The real humans are busy serving other customers  refilling the shelves with fine wares  or collaborating and deliberating on who in Britain really does have talent. The synthetic human is patiently waiting for some form of consent from their human masters to proceed. My fellow customers appear to look upon me with some malcontent  for they too are awaiting the purchase of goods such that they may return to their loved ones and prepare sustenance.  Eventually a real human appears and I can continue with my purchase  until such time as an  unexpected item  appears in the bagging area  despite this item being the bag which I tried so hard to introduce to the synthetic mere moments ago.  In summary  please  for the sake of all humanity  change the setting and allow our own bags to be automatically authorised by our faithful synthetic humans.  Thanking you in anticipation

column4: An email just sent to CEO! Dear Mr Coupe I write to you as a concerned and regular customer of Sainsburys near Richmond. I am aware that most slaughterhouses in the UK have now installed CCTV cameras due to concerns about the appalling treatment of animals therein. However  to my horror I have recently learned that 33 businesses in the UK and Wales ( a fifth of all those with CCTV) have refused to share the information provided with the FSA. It is not publicly known which slaughterhouses have refused to share such footage  In my view this is totally unacceptable behaviour. As you are probably aware efforts are now being made for CCTV to be made mandatory in all slaughterhouses and legislation passed to ensure that footage is available to official vets.   In the meantime I am aware that all leading supermarkets require slaughterhouses to have CCTV. However it is unclear whether supermarkets  including Sainsburys  ensure that the  footage from these slaughterhouses is firstly available and secondly is independently monitored.  Thank you in anticipation for your response
column9: Hi Jenny, this will now be dealt with by our executive team. Liz

column4: Hello! I am compelled to write as I wish to complain about my visit to the Sainsbury’s Heaton  Newcastle Superstore earlier this morning. First let me take you back to the sunny evening of the 6th May. I called in to the petrol station to fill up  went to pay the £46.19 with my debit card but unfortunately there seemed to be a problem as the card terminal was saying ‘Timed Out’  we tried a few more times and then on a different till but to no avail. The gentleman apologised profusely and explained that his colleague was on the phone to IT. I had to then go back over to the main store and withdraw cash in order to pay for my fuel. A bit of a pain in the ass but needs must and these things happen.  I now bring you back to current day  I noticed that my account was rather depleted with no reasonable explanation as to why. I logged on to online banking and noticed that the fuel payments which we had attempted back on the 6th had come out…..not once…not twice…..not three times…..but FIVE times! So thats £230.95 on fuel in 5 separate transactions!  So I head down to customer services armed with my bank statement hoping this would be resolved quickly and we could all then get on with our lives.  My first contact is with a lady who listened to my story and looked at my bank statement  no apology. She shouted over to her colleague who came over and I told him the sorry tale. No apology  I was told he would have to speak to his manager. He came back but again no apology or explanation as to what was going on and just barked “bank card” at me and then had the ordacity to pull a face! He made me feel as though this was my fault and I’ve never felt so uncomfortable. He then stated that as ‘Good Will’ they will give me back £184.76  Good Will?? Is he moonlighting as Robin Hood or something?  You took £230.95 which was not yours and you are giving me SOME of my own money back as ‘Good Will’? He then said that I couldn’t prove that I paid for the petrol with the £50 cash I withdrew so I wasn’t going to get the last £46.19.  I certainly didn’t rock up at the petrol station with an additional 4 jerry cans and fill them up to exactly £46.19 each because I was paranoid that if we did leave the EU and World War 3 started  it would cause some sort of oil crisis in the Middle East.  Surely some sort of investigation needs to be carried out as I was not the only person who had ‘failed’ card transactions that day and had to go to the cashpoint. Surely the tills couldn’t be closed off due to a mismatch?  I am grateful that I have £184.76 back  although it still hasn’t arrived in my account. I do wish to have this investigated as I believe that all of this can be proved and that you will refund me the last £46.19.
column9: Hi Anna, I'm really sorry about this. I completely understand your concerns and frustration with this. In order for this to be fully investigated, would you be able to confirm if you have your receipt from the transaction at the petrol station? Danny.

column9: Sainsbury's: There should be CCTV of the till showing Anna paid in cash. Be aware they WILL automatically delete the CCTV images after (I don't know), 24-48-72-however-many hours. I would suggest the store save this footage. If they do *not* save the footage, this suggests they have something to hide. The till register system should also have its own receipts built in, I'm sure every transaction is logged electronically on your side - whether paid in cash or by card. So I'm sure you must be able to track a 46.19 GBP cash transaction being made at the specified time. (Anna, can you specify the exact time, as precisely as possible? Also, perhaps, if there are multiple tills, which one you were at?)

column4: Hello! I am compelled to write as I wish to complain about my visit to the Sainsbury’s Heaton  Newcastle Superstore earlier this morning. First let me take you back to the sunny evening of the 6th May. I called in to the petrol station to fill up  went to pay the £46.19 with my debit card but unfortunately there seemed to be a problem as the card terminal was saying ‘Timed Out’  we tried a few more times and then on a different till but to no avail. The gentleman apologised profusely and explained that his colleague was on the phone to IT. I had to then go back over to the main store and withdraw cash in order to pay for my fuel. A bit of a pain in the ass but needs must and these things happen.  I now bring you back to current day  I noticed that my account was rather depleted with no reasonable explanation as to why. I logged on to online banking and noticed that the fuel payments which we had attempted back on the 6th had come out…..not once…not twice…..not three times…..but FIVE times! So thats £230.95 on fuel in 5 separate transactions!  So I head down to customer services armed with my bank statement hoping this would be resolved quickly and we could all then get on with our lives.  My first contact is with a lady who listened to my story and looked at my bank statement  no apology. She shouted over to her colleague who came over and I told him the sorry tale. No apology  I was told he would have to speak to his manager. He came back but again no apology or explanation as to what was going on and just barked “bank card” at me and then had the ordacity to pull a face! He made me feel as though this was my fault and I’ve never felt so uncomfortable. He then stated that as ‘Good Will’ they will give me back £184.76  Good Will?? Is he moonlighting as Robin Hood or something?  You took £230.95 which was not yours and you are giving me SOME of my own money back as ‘Good Will’? He then said that I couldn’t prove that I paid for the petrol with the £50 cash I withdrew so I wasn’t going to get the last £46.19.  I certainly didn’t rock up at the petrol station with an additional 4 jerry cans and fill them up to exactly £46.19 each because I was paranoid that if we did leave the EU and World War 3 started  it would cause some sort of oil crisis in the Middle East.  Surely some sort of investigation needs to be carried out as I was not the only person who had ‘failed’ card transactions that day and had to go to the cashpoint. Surely the tills couldn’t be closed off due to a mismatch?  I am grateful that I have £184.76 back  although it still hasn’t arrived in my account. I do wish to have this investigated as I believe that all of this can be proved and that you will refund me the last £46.19.
column9: 1st attempt at 15:47,1second, 2nd attempt at 15:48, 2 seconds, 3rd attempt at 15:49,3seconds, 4th attempt 15:49, 4 seconds and 5th attempt at 15:50,5 seconds then a cash withdrawal at 15.52, 45 seconds

column9: Robbie, get a life and give her the money back. Your company made an error. You should be more concerned about putting it right rather than getting an innocent party to demonstrate their actions on the day. You should also, at a minimum, reimburse her for the time wasted on the phone and in store. Poor service.

I have contacted the store and spoke to the active manager in the store, Kim. She is very sorry for this incident and would like to contact you directly to resolve this. Can you PM us your contact number so that I can pass it to Kim? Grant

So I head down to customer services armed with my bank statement hoping this would be resolved quickly and we could all then get on with our lives.  My first contact is with a lady who listened to my story and looked at my bank statement  no apology. She shouted over to her colleague who came over and I told him the sorry tale. No apology  I was told he would have to speak to his manager. He came back but again no apology or explanation as to what was going on and just barked “bank card” at me and then had the ordacity to pull a face! He made me feel as though this was my fault and I’ve never felt so uncomfortable. He then stated that as ‘Good Will’ they will give me back £184.76  Good Will?? Is he moonlighting as Robin Hood or something?  You took £230.95 which was not yours and you are giving me SOME of my own money back as ‘Good Will’? He then said that I couldn’t prove that I paid for the petrol with the £50 cash I withdrew so I wasn’t going to get the last £46.19.  I certainly didn’t rock up at the petrol station with an additional 4 jerry cans and fill them up to exactly £46.19 each because I was paranoid that if we did leave the EU and World War 3 started  it would cause some sort of oil crisis in the Middle East.  Surely some sort of investigation needs to be carried out as I was not the only person who had ‘failed’ card transactions that day and had to go to the cashpoint. Surely the tills couldn’t be closed off due to a mismatch?  I am grateful that I have £184.76 back  although it still hasn’t arrived in my account. I do wish to have this investigated as I believe that all of this can be proved and that you will refund me the last £46.19.
column9: Disgraceful behaviour on Sainsburys behalf . Hope all is sorted

column4: Hello! I am compelled to write as I wish to complain about my visit to the Sainsbury’s Heaton  Newcastle Superstore earlier this morning. First let me take you back to the sunny evening of the 6th May. I called in to the petrol station to fill up  went to pay the £46.19 with my debit card but unfortunately there seemed to be a problem as the card terminal was saying ‘Timed Out’  we tried a few more times and then on a different till but to no avail. The gentleman apologised profusely and explained that his colleague was on the phone to IT. I had to then go back over to the main store and withdraw cash in order to pay for my fuel. A bit of a pain in the ass but needs must and these things happen.  I now bring you back to current day  I noticed that my account was rather depleted with no reasonable explanation as to why. I logged on to online banking and noticed that the fuel payments which we had attempted back on the 6th had come out…..not once…not twice…..not three times…..but FIVE times! He then said that I couldn’t prove that I paid for the petrol with the £50 cash I withdrew so I wasn’t going to get the last £46.19. Surely some sort of investigation needs to be carried out as I was not the only person who had ‘failed’ card transactions that day and had to go to the cashpoint. column4: I bought one of your storage box graters (£8) a couple of weeks ago as they looked to be a clever design but it has actually turned out to be completely useless. Very disappointing. Could you let me know how I go about returning it please? I have my receipt but none of the original packaging.
column9: Hi Yvonne, as long as you have your receipt my colleagues in store will be able to sort you out with a refund. Liz

column4: I have to wonder what the point is of attaching vouchers to my online order (that I place on a weekly basis) that I am unable to use online? I have a very handy triple nectar points voucher that I would like to use on my weekly online shop that has no code and is therefore useless. Thanks for valuing loyal customers sainsburys.
column9: Sorry you're not a fan of the vouchers Sarah. Our vouchers are designed to encourage customers to shop with us in different ways. The vouchers are generated on your Nectar history so make sure you're scanning you card every time you shop. It'll help generate vouchers that are more suitable to you. Amanda.

If I wanted to go in store I'd do my shopping then! But how annoying Sarah to be out of range of the delivery service 😟 x

column4: Absolutely disgusted by the way my elderly grandmother and I were treated in your West Hove store today. I had coupons from Caring Everyday- partners with Johnson and Johnson  John West and Pringles through their official Facebook page and your staff were rude and accusing. They were obviously poorly trained as I had to ask the girl on the till to scan them as she didn t know what she was doing- and of course they were expected by your tills. My grandmother was asked to go to customer services where she was asked where she got the coupons and when I explained it was through the manufacturers I was made to feel a fraud  embarrassed and a liar with more clueless staff being called over to add to the confusion over something very simple. WORST customer service I have ever experienced. I ve been shopping there for around ten years but I will not be shopping at your stores again  disgraceful behaviour leaving my elderly grandmother very upset. You need to urgently deal with your rude staff. I hope no one else has to experience dirty looks from judgy sainsburies staff like we had to.
column9: Oh dear, not what we like to hear. Really sorry for the poor experience Jodie. What time were you & your grandmother visiting us today? Can you PM us the names/a description of the colleague who was rude to you? I'll ensure this is fed back to the store management team. Thanks, Kirsty

column4: I just wanted to write and tell you my Son and I had a REALLY upsetting experience at our local store on Saturday which all could have been avoided had I been given correct information by a staff member and then by other members of staff.  Thankfully a lovely customer  who saw it all happen helped me  sadly though it didn t stop my Son from being upset for over half an hour.  I always let you know when you do good  but  sadly on this occassion you did terrible.  This store has gone downhill recently and I personally now think Tesco s is beating yourselves hands down in all departments  not something I would have said a while back :(.
column9: Hi Ryan, I went to my local Thetford (Norfolk) store with my Son and had to go to customer service to return a couple of items of clothing, whilst there I said that I'd forgotten my nectar card but had a couple of coupons and would I still be able to use them, she said so long as I kept my receipt and did it within 14 days it would be fine.  I then continued to do my shopping, bought my Son a light sabre in it and then got to the till.  I told the lady that I'd forgotten my nectar card and handed her the coupons and she said I can't do that, I told her what customer services had stated and she said no you can't, but I'll check for you.  Bearing in mind this was for £12 off and also triple nectar points (so not something to be sniffed at), her supervisor said the same and I said I'd asked before shopping and she said well if the person hadn't seen the coupons then she wouldn't know (surely that was her job to ask to see them and not pressume).  My Son started crying so I felt obliged to pay the bill and then the customer behind me who had heard everything said don't pay.  She said they can put it away for you whereby you can go and get your card and then come back and pay for it, I said really, she said yes, they don't bother telling you that (bad a customer was more helpful than the staff).  This is exactly what I did and had my Son who's 5 sobbing in the car the whole way home and back again (30 mins).  Perhaps some staff training wouldn't go amiss and also teach them to be helpful like the customer was.  I would have returned home for the card had I been told and the upset wouldn't have happened.  Also, whilst having a down moment with your store, it was so sad to see that you weren't taking part in Coeliac awareness week.  Tesco had 3 for 2 on.  A present there's not a lot to encourage me to shop in your store anymore :(.

column9: 01779059 sandwich with minimal filling and no stock on shelves for the other items. Wish I had taken a photo. Store on kings Ave clapham

column4: Hello. I have had several TU items delivered to my local store (Bexhill  East Sussex) over the past few months  and its never been a pleasant experience when I collect/return. There are very few customer service staff who actually know what to do when I say I m collecting an order  so I nearly always have to wait for someone to come. It then takes an age for them to fiddle on the computer finding my order (because they re not really sure what they re doing)  and then I have to wait for forever while they go upstairs to fetch it. Its a very similar experience when returning an order. I usually have to allow 15mins for this process. The staff  while polite  are be no means friendly. I usually feel that I m causing a great inconvenience to them by having my order delivered to store and as such never feel welcome.   This mornings experience is what has compelled me to write something. I was returning an item of clothing - never worn  in original packing and with the paper order slip. The woman on the desk almost wouldn t accept it because I didn t have the blue outer packaging  which is essentially  just the carrier bag. I had to argue my case and she would only process the return with supervisor approval. Ok  I got my refund  but not without a fight.   I have to say  none of this makes me want to really order from you any more  and I won t pay postage to have it delivered to my house. I m not really expecting any follow up  just wanted you to know that Bexhill Sainsbuys are rubbish!   Kind Regards
column9: thank you for your reply. No i didn't get her name. I can't really remember what she looked like either! Old - but then most of them are in my store! short dark grey curly hair. can't give any more then that I'm afraid. she's always usually on the kiosk/customer service desk.

The woman on the desk almost wouldn t accept it because I didn t have the blue outer packaging  which is essentially  just the carrier bag. I had to argue my case and she would only process the return with supervisor approval. Ok  I got my refund  but not without a fight.   I have to say  none of this makes me want to really order from you any more  and I won t pay postage to have it delivered to my house. I m not really expecting any follow up  just wanted you to know that Bexhill Sainsbuys are rubbish!   Kind Regards
column9: You're welcome Emily. Amanda.

column4: Hello. I have had several TU items delivered to my local store (Bexhill  East Sussex) over the past few months  and its never been a pleasant experience when I collect/return. There are very few customer service staff who actually know what to do when I say I m collecting an order  so I nearly always have to wait for someone to come. It then takes an age for them to fiddle on the computer finding my order (because they re not really sure what they re doing)  and then I have to wait for forever while they go upstairs to fetch it. Its a very similar experience when returning an order. I usually have to allow 15mins for this process. The staff  while polite  are be no means friendly. I usually feel that I m causing a great inconvenience to them by having my order delivered to store and as such never feel welcome. I have to say  none of this makes me want to really order from you any more  and I won t pay postage to have it delivered to my house. I m not really expecting any follow up  just wanted you to know that Bexhill Sainsbuys are rubbish!   Kind Regards

column4: Was I disappointed today at sainsburys? Well yes I bought some rainbow veg with lime n coconut oil thought they would be lovely for tea with chicken ....    Why I didn t check for gluten I have no idea really usually always look at everything I pick up ...... So disappointed to find wheat/gluten added to fresh veg why do you need to spoil fresh food with wheat so many people out there don t have gluten and dairy now ....   How s about thinking about us for a change and offering food we can eat along with everyone else they won t miss the wheat in their veg they probably didn t even notice it s there anyway   Sooooooooo disappointed at sainsburys in Arnold   Oh and why not put on the label of other foods that it s gluten free instead of us having to read every label of every food we buy ???
column9: Hi Carol, we actually have a range which is called Freefrom that is designed for those with certain dietary requirements. You'll be able to find these items in the Freefrom section in Arnold and also online on our website. Are you able to send me a barcode from the product? I'll log your feedback for review with our buyers regarding the ingredients. Thanks, Ryan.

column4: Second time in a year I have been short changed of a ten pound note at the lottery/cigarette counter in the otley branch.Complain instantly to be told to leave my details and they will contact me! So I ask for the manager get a supervisor who asks if I would like them to check the CCTV ( obviously I would!) wait for 45 minutes with the lady who served me and made the mistake glaring and tutting at me! Twice in the 45 minutes the supervisor came out to say he was sorry it was taking so long ( why I have no idea as the time of transaction was evident in receipt and you are able to pause the CCTV) and again asked if I would like to leave and they would ring me later...explained I had waited long enough already and surely it would not be much longer...eventually the supervisor returns..asks if I want my money back in change or a note. No apology from the checkout woman who was very rude when I highlighted her mistake nor the supervisor! And left to sit in full view of your staff staring at me for the 45 minutes.As I stated earlier this is the second time in a year with the same member of staff although the first time I only had to wait about 5 minutes.I was absolutely disgusted at your service today!
column9: Sorry for the upset, Haley. When exactly did this happen? Chris.

column4: Second time in a year I have been short changed of a ten pound note at the lottery/cigarette counter in the otley branch.Complain instantly to be told to leave my details and they will contact me! column4: I just tried to help my elderly mum place an online grocery order with you. We spent an hour setting up her account and shopping.   She was worried that we would lose the trolley so I assured her it was fine and kept regulary saving it  and in turn  it assured us that even if we come away from the computer it was saved.   She wants to add to the order throughout the week and checkout on sunday. Again I promised her that she could do that.  She was fretting so I said  lets log out and I ll show you the trolley is still there . The website even said goodbye  assured us it was saved and we could finish our order any time.    I logged back in  lo and behold...empty trolley! Zero! Nothing!   Well  that made me look like a right numpty.   Complete waste of our time and one stressed mother! Needless to say  any online shops we do  will be with Tescos now  I am not wasting my time like that again.

column4: I have just returned from your Sainsbury s Local store and have had a very upsetting experience. I have been a loyal customer there since it opened and have been a loyal customer of Sainsbury s for a long time. Whilst reaching for a tub of powdered milk for my baby daughter  the aisle sign fell down smacking me and my 4 year old son who was in my arms in the face. The pain was excruciating and my son screamed the place down. It could have quite easily broken his nose. I was disgusted that not one member of staff came to our aid to see if we were ok and when I told the lady that served me  she simply said  oh sorry about that . I could not believe the complete lack of concern and indeed customer service. I would like to know how this is going to be addressed and indeed how I will be compensated.
column9: Really sorry Nicola, is your baby okay, what stoe was this? If you PM your address and a contact telephone number I'll pass this over to our executive team for investigation. Liz

column4: Sainsburys have now taken over sales of download material for NOOK eReaders  NOOK HD and NOOK HD+. My existing NOOK library has been transferred okay  but I can no longer purchase books&mags from NOOK UK or SAINSBURYS UK as I am presently in France (as was always the case with NOOK UK). Five NOOK machines can longer be added to because Sainsburys won t allow downloads...... B&N UK had no issues. DO I JUST THROW FIVE NOOKS AWAY NOW????? Can ANYONE in Sainsburys spend 30 seconds to suggest a solution????? Thanks  Ken
column9: Hi Ken, thanks for getting in touch. As you're based in France & to save you a call, I've given our Entertainment team a phone to ask your questions. They've advised the following: 1-  it can take up to 90 days for books to transfer over, however if we don't have them available the these would not be transferred. 2- if you have a UK bank account & registered UK address with the entertainment site, then you should be able to to access the site in France. If you don't have a UK address or bank, then unfortunately you wouldn't be able to use the site as we're a UK based company. I hope this information help! Thanks, Kirsty

column4: When we changed supermarkets last year I was amazed to find a flagship store like Sainsbuys Waterlooville had such a basic meat counter. Several times I ve asked for cuts of meat only to be told that  we don t sell them because they are too expensive  or  if we sold it we would throw to much of it away  . We are talking about Rib of Beef and Fillet Steak ! Wake up Sainsburys  all your competitors stock it or have offered to get it in if unavailable.  Rib roast is one of the most used joints of meat. Surely its down to me to decide if something is too expensive. Now today I ve been  informed that you no longer do our favourite cheese  Davidstow 3 year vintage cheddar . Come on Sainsburys.
column9: Sorry you're unhappy John. Our buyers monitor what does and doesn't sell in different stores and items are stocked based on this information. I'll log your concerns for consideration and we'll monitor any further feedback we receive for this. Do you happen to have a barcode for the cheese and I'll log that as well? Liz

column4: I know when buying fresh bread from your bakery we run the risk of seeds getting onto the non seeded bread but to find seeds running through the loaf of bread is not the best. I have just had to ring my sons school and get them to stop him eating his lunch as he can have an anaphylaxis attack if he ate it not best pleased with this it s never happened before :(
column9: I'm really sorry about that Jo. Unfortunately, all bakery products are at risk of cross contamination. What exactly happened? Can you send a picture of the barcode please? Can you also confirm which store the bread was bought from? Thanks, Naomi.

column9: It is a risk we know but we all enjoy the bread so much that we buy it this is the first time it's ever happened the seeds were inside the bread so not detectable when we purchased it yesterday, we got it from the Penzance store and will get a picture of the balcony and pop it on this post x

column4: Dear Sir/Madam  I am writing on behalf of St John Ambulance as we at the Winchester Unit have been given the challenge of raising £1000.  We will be holding a fun day at The Worthies Sports and Social Club on the 31st July. This will include some craft stalls  raffle and some fun and games with a bbq and live band.  As one of the major companies in the area  I was hoping you would be able to help us out with the donation of a raffle prize. This would be great appreciated. column4: It is with a heavy heart that I write this post. I purchase all of my shopping from Sainsbury s  at Chafford Hundred  Thurrock  with deliveries taking place twice most weeks. Most of the delivery crew are lovely  polite  kind and always baring a smile. However  in the past few weeks  I have had one called Julia  who is nothing more than a thug. She approaches my door like a hitman  deliberately pulling up her sleeves to display the huge tattoos on her generous biceps. She talks to the customer like she s a 13-year-old chav who s sole purpose is to make the residents of the street they re on suffer. You know the ones  the ones who proudly boast about their ASBOS like it s a university doctorate? Well  anyway  that’s the only way to describe the behaviour of this Julia Pritchard character. I digress. Back to my complaint  I am a woman of almost 40 years  with a daughter that approaches 20 in a few short weeks. Unfortunately  due health complications  I can’t always be the person to greet the driver and receive my groceries  but my daughter never fails to open the door with the manners that have been instilled in her since birth. Julio came a couple of weeks back and got irate with my daughter because in her own words ‘she looks under 25’. Well  I should hope so  seeing as she’s net met her second decade yet. My daughter pointed out that she never get’s Id’d by any of the other drivers  and seeing as there is never alcohol or other restricted items and that the house was clearly undergoing major constructions  asked was it really necessary. Julio argued her point  and my daughter gracefully relented. There were a couple of substitutions on the list so my daughter called out to me to ask if they were suitable. Upon hearing my voice  Julio  took great offence and told me to “get up and sign for my own shopping!” Now  after paying for a service  and having my adult daughter present to sign for the groceries  do you think that was appropriate? For all she knew  I could’ve been laid up with a full body cast! Anyway  my daughter expressed her displeasure at her blatant disrespect for her mother to which the delivery girl responded with shouting and swearing  and a whole lot of stepping up into my daughters space in order to look down upon her. I  of course telephoned head office to complain  and was assured that they didn’t want to lose a customer and that I wouldn’t have to lay eyes upon her again… Having caught you up to speed  this brings us to this morning. A rapturous knocking on my front door sent my little dog into a frenzy  so I instructed my daughter to remove him so that the delivery person wouldn’t be exposed to any threat. Once it was in hand  I opened the door with the same smile I use to greet everyone. The first thing that struck me was the offensive stance of this woman. And the second was that she seemed unprepared to see me standing there. After recovering from her shock  she groused  in a most unpleasant manner  “Oh  are you signing for the shopping this week?” Odd  no? I responded  nonetheless. “Yes.” She regarded me for a moment before hitting me with the most ridiculous request. “I need ID…” I laughed  and asked  “Are you serious?” “Yeah!” was her gruff response. Of course  this only served to aggravate me  as anyone and their blind grandma can see that I’m over 25 –four decades  remember?– Anyhow  I told her that I certainly will not be producing identification  that I’m almost 40 years old  and that the ID she saw only recently was that of my adult daughter. She made a flip remark under her breath  to which I reminded her  this happened a couple of weeks ago with her. She responded with a wolfish grin  “You don’t want your shopping  then?” I do not negotiate with those who try to terrorise me. So I asked her why she was here  I was assured by head office that I wouldn’t have to deal with her unpleasantness again. My weekly grocery bill alone is probably more than she gets paid. Anyway  with that  she threw my paperwork at me  told me to “Shop at Asda ” and walked away with my groceries still on her van. Now  I wish to point out that I have been using Sainsbury’s online shopping for in excess of a year now  and have only ever had two complaints. Both times it has been with her. I don’t know her or anything about her  so why would I have any problem with her? I ask you  would you put up with being treated this way in your own home? I have been up to the store AND have called the online delivery helpline to complain about this matter. I am posting this because I want something done about this menacing woman. If she’s treating me like this  then I’m sure she’s the same way with other innocent service users. My biggest fear is that she may be doing this to the more vulnerable members of society  the elderly  for example  especially those who are too afraid to speak out for fear of reprisal.  Please feel free to share this post  especially if you’ve found yourself the victim of a power mad delivery boy. You do not have to tolerate bullying  regardless of what these bullies say. Empower the weak. Empower yourself.
column9: Sure thing!

I  of course telephoned head office to complain  and was assured that they didn’t want to lose a customer and that I wouldn’t have to lay eyes upon her again… Having caught you up to speed  this brings us to this morning. A rapturous knocking on my front door sent my little dog into a frenzy  so I instructed my daughter to remove him so that the delivery person wouldn’t be exposed to any threat. Once it was in hand  I opened the door with the same smile I use to greet everyone. The first thing that struck me was the offensive stance of this woman. And the second was that she seemed unprepared to see me standing there. After recovering from her shock  she groused  in a most unpleasant manner  “Oh  are you signing for the shopping this week?” Odd  no? I responded  nonetheless. “Yes.” She regarded me for a moment before hitting me with the most ridiculous request. “I need ID…” I laughed  and asked  “Are you serious?” “Yeah!” was her gruff response. Of course  this only served to aggravate me  as anyone and their blind grandma can see that I’m over 25 –four decades  remember?– Anyhow  I told her that I certainly will not be producing identification  that I’m almost 40 years old  and that the ID she saw only recently was that of my adult daughter. She made a flip remark under her breath  to which I reminded her  this happened a couple of weeks ago with her. She responded with a wolfish grin  “You don’t want your shopping  then?” I do not negotiate with those who try to terrorise me. So I asked her why she was here  I was assured by head office that I wouldn’t have to deal with her unpleasantness again. My weekly grocery bill alone is probably more than she gets paid. Anyway  with that  she threw my paperwork at me  told me to “Shop at Asda ” and walked away with my groceries still on her van. Now  I wish to point out that I have been using Sainsbury’s online shopping for in excess of a year now  and have only ever had two complaints. Both times it has been with her. I don’t know her or anything about her  so why would I have any problem with her? I ask you  would you put up with being treated this way in your own home? I have been up to the store AND have called the online delivery helpline to complain about this matter. I am posting this because I want something done about this menacing woman. If she’s treating me like this  then I’m sure she’s the same way with other innocent service users. My biggest fear is that she may be doing this to the more vulnerable members of society  the elderly  for example  especially those who are too afraid to speak out for fear of reprisal.  Please feel free to share this post  especially if you’ve found yourself the victim of a power mad delivery boy. You do not have to tolerate bullying  regardless of what these bullies say. Empower the weak. Empower yourself.
column9: Here's a useful link Donna: http://bit.ly/1uxieWG. Neil.

column4: It is with a heavy heart that I write this post. I purchase all of my shopping from Sainsbury s  at Chafford Hundred  Thurrock  with deliveries taking place twice most weeks. Most of the delivery crew are lovely  polite  kind and always baring a smile. However  in the past few weeks  I have had one called Julia  who is nothing more than a thug. She approaches my door like a hitman  deliberately pulling up her sleeves to display the huge tattoos on her generous biceps. She talks to the customer like she s a 13-year-old chav who s sole purpose is to make the residents of the street they re on suffer. You know the ones  the ones who proudly boast about their ASBOS like it s a university doctorate? Well  anyway  that’s the only way to describe the behaviour of this Julia Pritchard character. I digress. Back to my complaint  I am a woman of almost 40 years  with a daughter that approaches 20 in a few short weeks. Unfortunately  due health complications  I can’t always be the person to greet the driver and receive my groceries  but my daughter never fails to open the door with the manners that have been instilled in her since birth. Julio came a couple of weeks back and got irate with my daughter because in her own words ‘she looks under 25’. Well  I should hope so  seeing as she’s net met her second decade yet. My daughter pointed out that she never get’s Id’d by any of the other drivers  and seeing as there is never alcohol or other restricted items and that the house was clearly undergoing major constructions  asked was it really necessary. Julio argued her point  and my daughter gracefully relented. There were a couple of substitutions on the list so my daughter called out to me to ask if they were suitable. Upon hearing my voice  Julio  took great offence and told me to “get up and sign for my own shopping!” Now  after paying for a service  and having my adult daughter present to sign for the groceries  do you think that was appropriate? For all she knew  I could’ve been laid up with a full body cast! column4: Your Kelso store is really providing an increasingly unpleasant shopping experience. Every so often  shoppers are subject to moronic  blaring adverts which do not encourage people to stay in the shop. People with hearing/neurological problems/autism/hyperacusis can be made very uncomfortable by this needless racket. It is the 21st century and therefore high time you had a properly comprehensive disability policy. Blasting people out with trashy ads is not the way to retain customers.

column4: I notice today that you ve trebled the fee for my usual delivery slot???? Getting a bit greedy are we?
column9: I don't think it's a mistake, a lot of the £1 slots seem to have been increased. I usually book mine for 11-12 on a Thursday, which has been £1 since I started online shopping. According to the website it's £3 now. That's a massive increase in just a week. The only £1 slots I could find were for Wednesday, at the most inconvenient times for me.

column4: I notice today that you ve trebled the fee for my usual delivery slot???? Getting a bit greedy are we?
column9: You think it's greedy to expect people to pay more than one pound to have their shopping picked, packed and delivered to their door???

column4: I notice today that you ve trebled the fee for my usual delivery slot???? Getting a bit greedy are we?
column9: Personally I think the delivery drivers do a great job, they're friendly, polite and helpful. They are well worth a £3 fee and I paid it but it's the way they've done it that grates a bit. Increasing the fee by 300% in the space of a week is extortionate IMHO.

column4: I notice today that you ve trebled the fee for my usual delivery slot???? Getting a bit greedy are we?
column9: Hi Helen, the prices for home delivery slots are subject to change and can fluctuate in price based on availability and demand. It may be that there are more, or less, deliveries than usual in your area and this can affect the price of the slot. On this occasion however, I've issued a £2 e-voucher for you to apply to your order so you can still get your delivery slot for £1. It should be with you via e-mail within 15 minutes. I hope you have a lovely evening! Ryan.

column4: I notice today that you ve trebled the fee for my usual delivery slot???? Getting a bit greedy are we?
column9: Thanks for the voucher, I'm not whinging for the sake of getting a refund, I just hope you take note of the feedback - I understand that prices change according to demand, but after over a year at a fixed price, a 300% increase is hardly what one could call a 'fluctuation'!

column4: I notice today that you ve trebled the fee for my usual delivery slot???? Getting a bit greedy are we?

column4: Dear Sainsbury s  Re: Volunteer Art  Here s my suggestion: 1. Apologise  without reservation  for this bungling error. 2. column4: Congratulations  Sainsbury: Another CON.  About 5 days ago I complained about the disappearance from the shelves of the very popular Black Seedless Grapes (£1.50 a punnet).   Guess What!!?? They’ve re-appeared this morning (Sunday)....at £2.00 a punnet.  Do you think we customers are Stupid? Don’t you make enough profit each week?  ....No wonder we’ve all disappeared off to Aldi and Lidl. NOT Impressed  Sainsbury. Another attempted con on the customer.
column9: Having worked (many years ago) in Supermarket retail, it's a very common con trick to put your prices up....you withdraw a very popular line, give it some time to build up a demand, and then suddenly re-introduce it at an increased price, and hope that the customers will accept the new price. The usual excuses are ""Well, we've had a new delivery and the base prices have gone up..."" [and yet, why have other stores / supermarkets who stock this line not increased Their prices? [[To be honest, Fraser, this sounds like a message from someone inside Sainsbury. Am I right?]]

column4: Just back from my Sunday shop in your Sprucefield store and I have to say I m losing a bit of faith now. Over the past few weeks I ve noticed that the variety and availability of products is vastly reduced. So far I ve been unable to regularly source avocados 4pk  blueberries  Vittoria tomatoes  5% mince steak  taste the difference Peruvian chocolate and your own label of spices. While some are available one week they definitely won t be the next. This is only a few of the items that are included in my weekly shop but it makes it very frustrating when I then have to go to another shop to find the rest. It feels as though the shop is closing down the shelves are so empty at times. 😡
column9: Hi Tara, all of our products are subject to availability while stocks last however in regards to the spices, we're currently reviewing our range and will be launching a brand new line on June 12 but we've taken these products off-sale until then. I've had a look on the store's stock system and I can see the store had around 45 four-packs of ripen at home avocado today, but our ripe & ready avocado are currently on hold and that will be why you haven't seen those particular ones in stock. Our store are currently awaiting a delivery tomorrow of the Vittoria vine tomatoes too, which is great news. As for the mince, did you ask for any assistance in store? I can see we had plenty in stock, however the store accepted an additional delivery today so there will be more on shelf tomorrow. I hope this helps. Ryan.

column4: It would be nice if you actually contacted customers to tell them that their home delivery isn t coming. Don t worry yourselves though  we popped into Tesco instead. Much better at customer service.
column9: Sorry you had a poor experience Lauren. Can you give us some more information please? Thanks, Naomi.

column4: Hi  I hope you can help.   I went shopping in your Eastleigh shop(next to the bus station and in the town centre).  I was very unhappy with a member of staff.  As I approached the lifts at the top of the carpark the children decided to race me to the bottom as I waited for the lift by using the stairs. You had an employee with trolleys waiting for the lift.  As I waited he was very visibly shacking his head. The lift arrived and I put my hand in front of the door. Your employee was still annoyed at me  so I said to him  there is enough room in here if you want to come in?  he shook his head and told me that  Its fine  you go ahead. I know my place.  I was shocked and said  Sorry?  there is room in here for you too  He then told me  You are obviously more important then me!  He was very aggressive and it made me very annoyed and upset.  I went straight to customer service and made a complaint. The chap there was very pleasant and told me that the guy is  special . He was referring to the fact that the guy upstairs has learning difficulties I think. I was also told that sometimes he doesn t necessarily know what he is saying.  I met up with my wife who had arranged to meet myself and the kids and I explained to her  and she told me that the same guy on a previous visit had rammed her with trollies as she waited for a lift.  As I did my shopping and came back round  I saw the  special  guy speaking to security and the man I spoke to at customer service.  When I went back to the car  he was at the top again just staring at me.  I understand that you are an equal opportunities employer and that any member of the public would allow for people with learning issues and I would do exactly the same  but your employee made me very upset.  I think you should really look at whether this is the place for this guy in particular. Your other employee made it clear to me that I am not the first to complain about him and within our immediate family he has upset myself and my wife.  I would really think about returning to that store.  I look forward to hearing from you.  Regards  Johnathon Dewey
column9: I'm really sorry the customer service wasn't up to scratch Johnathon. Could you PM the time you were in store and a description of the colleague? Leigh

column4: Rats! I use Sainsbury s Pharmacy to collect my prescription from - great service! But! Sainsburys have sold the pharmacy business to Lloyds - one reason for choosing Sainsburys was that they weren t Lloyds! Oh well maybe Lloyds have improved - a lot - over the years!
column9: Hi Anthony, our partnership with Lloyds Pharmacy is simply to ensure that we can continue to support you with these products and services in the best way possible. Your prescriptions will still be managed the exact same way, it will be the same colleagues as before and we'll still be able to collect your prescription directly from your GP. If there's anything at all you're concerned about, feel free to speak to your pharmacist on your next visit and they'll be happy to discuss it with you! Ryan.

column4: Dear Sainsburys    I am devastated. My 15 year old daughter is allergic to your ultimate lemon washing up liquid. And I bought three bottles. Do you understand the repercussions of this?! Do you know how hard it is to get a 15 year old girl to do the washing up? Do you realise how long it will take me to get her to wash up again?!?! This could potentially set the evolution of teenagers back hundreds of years.   Happy to be compensated in chocolate or prosecco 😆  Regards   Amy xx
column9: Hi Amy, thanks for letting us know - more importantly is your daughter okay? Can you send me a picture of the barcode and the store you bought this in? Ryan.

column4: I am dismayed to learn that Sainsbury s pharmacy will be absorbed by Lloyds pharmacy shortly. I have had excellent service from my local store pharmacy for some time. I switched to Sainsbury s due to the poor service at my local Lloyds branch. Looks like I will have to find a new supplier. What a pity when an efficient  friendly  service is swallowed up by the inevitable corporate steam roller.
column9: Hi Tony, thanks for getting in touch. We've partnered with Lloyds Pharmacy so that we can continue to support you with these products and services in the best way possible and although the name will be changing, the way prescriptions are managed will be same. It will also still be the same colleagues in the pharmacy, and we can continue to collect your prescription directly from your GP. Oh, and the opening hours will stay the same too. I hope this eases any worry you might have about the partnership. Ryan.

column4: How about discounts for service Veterans like they give in the USA?
column9: I hope you aren't planning on doing any shopping soon then Jill....there are literally 100's of companies and stores that take part in the Defence Discount Card scheme! Hope you don't use Sky or Virgin too, as they have signed up! Want to go on holiday? Better check the tour operator you use because plenty of them are signed up too!!!  But it will save you loads of money no doubt....so that's a bonus eh?!!!  And if you did a bit of research, you might have found this.....  https://www.bluelightcard.co.uk/index.php?p=nhsdiscounts  So there you go, these highly valued workers do get discounts, like our highly valued veterans and serving armed forces personnel.

column4: How about discounts for service Veterans like they give in the USA?
column9: Lots of groups of people get discounts all the time, I'm surprised that people would resent it for the armed forces.  People working for the NHS do get discounts, more generally most places have reduced prices for children, students, people claiming certain benefits, people who qualify for state pension etc.    People who wear a uniform to work or provide their own tools, equipment or pay for membership to professional bodies can claim tax back for it, although this uniform tax break excludes the armed forces for some reason.  And it's not because the uniform is provided and washed for them, because that's not the case.  They often have to buy pieces of kit and are responsible for washing it all.   Best add going to certain cinemas, theme parks, coffee shops, fast food outlets to the list of companies you won't use, as lots of them offer a forces discount. In fact, best ask every single business you use what discounts they offer, and to whom, before you give them your money.

column4: How about discounts for service Veterans like they give in the USA?

column4: How about discounts for service Veterans like they give in the USA?
column9: Why would anyone resent giving a modest discount to people that put their lives on the line on a daily basis, to protect the country that we live in?!  I agree, NHS, emergency workers etc do this too so should also be considered. Do we not think this is just a small way of saying 'thank you' to those that serve us? We regularly tip waitresses, hairdressers, taxi drivers etc. just consider this a 'tip' for the public sector workers!

column4: I fail to understand why there are never enough staff behind the counter in your cafe in Enfield  A10. Today  the quest  as always was almost at the door  and there is one person serving and inadequately making hot drinks  then to be joined by a colleague to have unnecessarily long  chat about another customers  requirements. The queue now becoming increasing frustrated  caffeine needs going unmet! Our displeasure was responded to with little more than a pathetic attempt at an apology. Finally my order gets taken   only to be given a Chai latte  made with coffee  so now an even longer wait for my order  by now I really wish I d gone to Costa! I eventually get my husbands Chai latte and my latte and await my bacon butty. Which arrives quickly  but cold and on stale bread!  congratulations to you for providing the most stressful and unpleasant visit to date! COSTA ALL THE WAY FOR ME FROM NOW ON!

column4: Phoned your pharmacist today hoping my husbands repeat prescription had been put on the online prescription (which it hadn t) so phoned 111 nhs who were brilliant and told me that I could go into any pharmacy and they can call and get it sorted! So I came into one of your branches who the pharmacist was least impressed that I dared asked him to do it and asked me to come back as it would take a long time and he wanted his lunch! So I did! My husband then went in  to be asked the same as me can he not just use over the counter until Monday which I had already said many time does not work! Then for him to be told do you have a phone because this will take hours (I know it does not!) he said yes and that s fine!.. After privately talking with other staff said sorry he can not do it the fax machine is broken! He clearly did not want to do it to start! Whilst both me and my husband both previously work at that store knowing states there s another one upstairs! Well apparently not according to your useless staff! Also it s called and online perception! Doctors sign online! No need for faxing! Thanks sainsburys for not doing your job but going that extra mile to piss me off I won t go back!!
column9: Oh, I'm so sorry Becky, can you PM us the store in question and also the name of the colleague please? Maryclare

column4: Dear Sainsbury s I feel the need to post on here after having breakfast in your Biggleswade store. I felt quite upset after leaving. The cafe was quite busy and the staff were really doing an excellent job. They were some delays with the food coming out  however I think this was due to the demand alone and definitely not due to the staff who were working so very hard. This led to some frustration with some customers and this was directed at the staff. I witnessed this and the young girl who was working the till dealt with it in an amazing manner  she was so polite and professional. However she was clearly upset by the conversation (and quite rightly so) and I really felt for her. They staff must surely feel so demoralised after working in such conditions and it is very unfair. I wanted to post this on here as I am hoping for 2 things. 1. For this to be recognised and for the staff to perhaps be given some more support at what is bound to be a busy period. 2. For the staff to know that they are very much appreciated and undeserving of such criticism.  Could you please feed this back to the Biggleswade store?  Many thanks  Jane
column9: Thanks Jane. When did this happen? Can you PM us the name of the colleague or perhaps her description? I'll certainly make sure this is fed back to the store for you. Amanda.

column4: Just want to say a huge thank you and special mention to Stephen in the bakery department at tollgate  Colchester.  My husband went in yesterday to purchase one of the Thomas cakes for our sons 3rd birthday tomorrow and there wasn t any in stock. Stephen went above and beyond to ensure we could have one by today and personally called us to confirm there would be a delivery today and then again this morning to say he had put one aside for us.   My husband has just collected it so Stephen certainly saved the day! Fantastic customer service and seemed genuinely more than happy to help us. I m 8 months pregnant so certainly didn t fancy going from store to store to find an alternative and our son is Thomas mad so I m so pleased he ll have it for his party 😊  I hope this reaches him somehow.  Thank you again 😊👍🏼

column9: Sorry you're unhappy about the pricing Stu. We try to remain competitive and constantly review our pricing. Although we try to keep our pricing as fair as possible sometimes prices can go up as well as down. There are lots of factors which can affect pricing, from rising costs of raw materials, to the production and packaging and even transportation.  Whilst we try to absorb these increases for as long as possible, sometimes we eventually have to put the price up. We'll ensure that your comments are logged for our buying team. Thanks, Kirsty

column4: Having been a loyal Sainsburys shopper for many years I am disappointed at the decision to stop the brand match. I was lead to believe that this was to reduce prices across the stores. At present I have only noticed an increase in store prices. The Eric the Elephant snacks have gone up by 30p in 4 weeks and having price compared 2 other branded products between stores  one was  90 p cheaper in morrisons  and the other  outside of the offer period was 40p cheaper also in Morrisons.  If the prices continue to increase it will become uneconomical to shop at Sainsburys.
column9: I'm sorry about this Pippa. As you have stated, we removed this service at the advise of our customers who wanted lower prices across the board, rather than the brand match service. Grant

column4: Dear Sainsburys  I recently went to the zoo with my missus and son. We had a lovely day looking at  and interacting with  the animals there. On the way home we stopped off at our local Sainsburys store to pick up some groceries. One of the things we bought was an 800g loaf of Giraffe Bread. However  despite the name  imagine my son s disappointment upon returning home and tearing into the bread  only to find it contained no giraffes. Not even one. Not even a little one. Understandably he felt cheated and betrayed by the Sainsburys brand and was all for vowing never to spend his money in Sainsburys again  instead planning on saving up for a loaf of Tiger bread from Asda  as he likes tigers almost as much as he likes giraffes. I reassured him that I would write to you and urge you to put warning stickers on the loaves so that other children do not fall foul of this fair trading faux pas. What next... chicken curry without the chicken? Belgian buns with no Belgians in? What stunt are you trying to pull here  Sainsburys  tricking little kids out of their pocket money?
column9: Hey there Ken! I hope your son isn't too disappointed. You can read why it's called giraffe bread here: http://tinyurl.com/gtfx2kh. Chris.

I reassured him that I would write to you and urge you to put warning stickers on the loaves so that other children do not fall foul of this fair trading faux pas. What next... chicken curry without the chicken? Belgian buns with no Belgians in? What stunt are you trying to pull here  Sainsburys  tricking little kids out of their pocket money?
column9: Thanks for the prompt clarification, Chris, as soon as the little urchin is old enough to read I shall be sure to explain where his assumptions led him down the wrong path. While you're on, do you have any literature explaining where exactly you're sourcing your shepherds from, for the Taste The Difference Shepherds Pie? I come from a farming area myself and I'd hate to think I was eating any of my old pals.

column4: Dear Sainsburys  I recently went to the zoo with my missus and son. We had a lovely day looking at  and interacting with  the animals there. On the way home we stopped off at our local Sainsburys store to pick up some groceries. One of the things we bought was an 800g loaf of Giraffe Bread. However  despite the name  imagine my son s disappointment upon returning home and tearing into the bread  only to find it contained no giraffes. Not even one. Not even a little one. Understandably he felt cheated and betrayed by the Sainsburys brand and was all for vowing never to spend his money in Sainsburys again  instead planning on saving up for a loaf of Tiger bread from Asda  as he likes tigers almost as much as he likes giraffes. I reassured him that I would write to you and urge you to put warning stickers on the loaves so that other children do not fall foul of this fair trading faux pas. What next... chicken curry without the chicken? Belgian buns with no Belgians in? What stunt are you trying to pull here  Sainsburys  tricking little kids out of their pocket money?
column9: Looks normal enough to me?

column4: I see you;re looking for an artist to refurbish your staff canteeen in Camden  but you don t want to pay them one penny. You think this will be a great opportunity for the artist (to produce art for you for no money) and to be recognised in the local area.  What a great idea! I ve therefore suggested to all my Facebook friends that they do the following:  Everyone should pop into your local Sainsbury s tomorrow lunchtime  and help yourselves to some nice goods off the shelves  perhaps a nice warm pastie  or a tasty sandwich. On your way out  without going near any tills  take a note to the customer services desk on which you have written   In order to help you get your goods recognised in the local area  I am going to sit on a bench outside  eating your lovely product. I will tell anyone passing how delicious this product is  thus enhancing your reputation in the area. This unique opportunity to get your work recognised will cost you nothing and will enable you to leave your mark on this community. There s no need to thank me. Good afternoon.  And then walk out.  Pay proper money to artists you miserable cheapskates!
column9: I really hope you do as you say

column4: Hi Ive just been shopping in the wantage store  stopped at the kiosk on my way out to buy a scratch card and once again I have been asked to show some ID. This happens every time I want to but scratch cards although I buy alcohol and I m never asked for some reason as soon as I want a scratch card I m always asked. I m 32 years old I certainly do not look under 16. I m getting sick of being asked  as today I didn t have my driving licence with me as its in the post getting my address changed on it. I was made to feel like a naughty little girl doing something I shouldn t be. I m a married woman with 4 children  my daughter will be old enough to buy them in a few years and yet I m still asked. I know the law says you have to be 16 to buy them  and I know your policy is to ask if anyone looks under 25 but again I am obviously not under 16 and they way I was spoken today made me feel like a child in front of a queue full of people. I had to walk away like I d done something wrong. This wouldn t bother me if it was every now and again but it s every time I try to buy them it s just getting stupid now.
column9: Hi there, we do have a think 25 policy in place, however, we do ask our colleagues to use there common sense in situations like this. I'm very sorry about your experience. Maryclare

column9: OK... so it's not new policy then? Ways to benefit the local community would be to fund local charities, financially support food banks and soup kitchens, have free events for elderly/ disabled/ unemployed. Asking a struggling artist to work on a project of that scale for free is just exploitation. This image is all over my timeline and the creative community are up in arms. Much damage done. As I say, you were my supermarket of choice but this leaves a very bad taste in the mouth. xxx

column4: Wow. You charge us for every item  but expect an artist to work for free just to be associated with your name? column9: It's more like Sainsbury's thinking that a struggling artist owes THEM something - a week or two of professional work for free. My local store do collect for the food bank... items purchased by us, the customers. They have a noticeboard of things they do for charity, so if a store were donating money, time, goods or events, we'd know about it. As a writer I am often asked to do events, book festivals, workshops etc for free and to write pieces too. When I was a teacher, nobody ever asked me to work for nothing. Do you work for free Matt? I do indeed do freebies now, but for good causes rather than for multi million corporations who can more than afford to pay a fair fee for a good job. xxx

column4: Hello   I just want to flag up how good your Chapelford  Warrington store is. I just called into the supermarket cafe with my 3-year-old and brand new baby. We had registered his birth and to celebrate my toddler wanted lunch at the supermarket - he thinks that s a huge treat.  We ordered our food  at which point I realised I had brought my husband s card and not mine  so I didn t know the PIN. It was very embarrassing but I had to ask them to hold our food back while I drove home for my purse. My 3 year old was upset and my baby was fussing for a feed - so it was quite stressful! Then a man (unaccountably dressed as Danger Mouse) stepped in  introduced himself as the manager and said he had children himself and there would be no charge for our meal.   We re regular Sainsbury s customers anyway  but this kind of compassionate response to a flustered mum with a newborn just shows what a good shop it is. Thanks a lot.
column9: Hello, it was lunchtime today - 13th May. Hope you can reiterate my thanks.

column4: Hi there. I d like to report one of your delivery drivers for dangerous driving. The gentleman spent the entirety of a two-three mile long  50mph speed-limit road around two metres distance from the rear of my vehicle  used incorrect lanes to attempt to hop a moving traffic que at traffic lights  and indicated that he wanted to re-enter the correct lane in a dangerous manner. Unable to do so  he then held up traffic in the wrong lane whilst waiting for an opportunity to return  and then returned to driving within 2 metres of my vehicle whilst I patiently waited for a cyclist to reach an appropriate point at which I could pass safely. The number plate of the van was PK56 SYS  and the driver appeared to be an older gentlemen of around 45-60 years of age.  Please keep me informed as to what your company is prepared to do in this instance  as I felt I was pressured to exceed the speed limit (something I did not do)  and feared there could be a crash. I find it astounding that somebody who drives for a living could do so in such an unsafe and aggressive manner.
column9: Apologies, the number plate was PK65 SYS

column4: STOP SELLING ROUNDUP _ IT IS CARCINOGENIC !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
column9: seriously? - if you take environmental effects seriously then take a known carcinogen off your shelves - it is both dangerous to the environment and to the people who use it - the people who make this product are the same people who made(make) Agent Orange which was used as a defoliant in the war in Vietnam - the chemicals used then are some of the same chemicals used in RoundUp - the birth defects are still being seen in Vietnam today - 30 yrs after the war was over - !!! it is also effecting the water table and the quality of any food grown - it is a very harmful substance and should not be allowed to appear for sale anywhere - your customers need to know that RoundUp is lethal - toxic - unnecessary- and CARCINOGENIC !!!!

column4: STOP SELLING ROUNDUP _ IT IS CARCINOGENIC !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
column9: Comparing nearly 12 million gallons of Agent Orange aerial dropped over  Vietnam is hardly in the same league as a few people spraying their weeds. The concentration cloud dropped in Vietnam was at least 13 times more than the domestic product available today.

column4: STOP SELLING ROUNDUP _ IT IS CARCINOGENIC !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
column9: Hi Hilary. we take the environmental effects of both our own products and branded ones we supply such as these pesticides very seriously. We will of course continue to monitor the situation to make sure that we’re continuing to meet all our customers’ needs as best we can. Leigh

column4: STOP SELLING ROUNDUP _ IT IS CARCINOGENIC !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
column9: cigarettes have health warnings - cigarettes are banned from being smoked in public places - no such warnings on RoundUp -

column4: Hi - I ve just purchased a tube (Travel Size) of Garnier Ambre Solaire Protection Lotion Ultra Hydrating SPF50 from my local Sainsburys. I purchased it specifically due to Garnier using Mexoryl® SX which is an exceptionally photostable sun filter. Before putting it on  looking at the ingredients  there is no Mexoryl but Avobenzone which is very photo unstable. I then looked at the date of manufacture and saw that it is 22H103 which is January 2011 - which probably is why no Mexoryl and which is way past the 36 month shelf life recommended by Garnier. This is really dangerous for an SPF product. Please can you advise? Thank you
column9: Sorry about this Kath. Can you PM me a pic of the barcode and product info on the item and the name of the store it was from? I can look into this. Susanna

column4: Hi - I ve just purchased a tube (Travel Size) of Garnier Ambre Solaire Protection Lotion Ultra Hydrating SPF50 from my local Sainsburys. I purchased it specifically due to Garnier using Mexoryl® SX which is an exceptionally photostable sun filter. Before putting it on  looking at the ingredients  there is no Mexoryl but Avobenzone which is very photo unstable. I then looked at the date of manufacture and saw that it is 22H103 which is January 2011 - which probably is why no Mexoryl and which is way past the 36 month shelf life recommended by Garnier. This is really dangerous for an SPF product. Please can you advise? Thank you
column9: That's right - but all products have a manufacture date. And L'real/Garnier advise that their products have a 36 month shelf life after the manufacture date. You can google for the details Whilst probably not an issue for most stuff, just meaning for example active ingredients wouldn't be active after that time maybe - for sun filters, that is very dangerous if they become inactive or not effective.

column4: Hi - I ve just purchased a tube (Travel Size) of Garnier Ambre Solaire Protection Lotion Ultra Hydrating SPF50 from my local Sainsburys. column9: They don't usually advertise a use by date. Just a ""use within X months of opening"" date

column4: Hi is it true that you are withdrawing the multibuy offers? As a mother with several kids  I find these multibuys invaluable to spread the weekly shopping budget and a large amount of my shopping trolley is items on offers or multibuys. I am really disappointed if it s true that you are withdrawing them. Also I tend to buy a lot of your Basics range to make our money go further  however over the last year I have been really disappointed to see quite a number of Basics items disappearing from the shelves - 12 pack of snack crisps was one which was really handy for the kids packed lunches and there are many more that have just gone that were really useful. Also many of these Basics items are no longer as good value for money as they used to be as the price keeps sliding upwards. (eg the bakery section morning goods - the basics crumpets  scotch pancakes and muffins used to be very cheap and now they are not! I also noticed last week that the multipack of basics sausage rolls suddenly shrank from an 8 pack to 6 and the price remains the same! I don t really think that is on! An 8 pack was a better size for our family too. I am really disappointed and would like Sainsbury s to consider expanding their Basics range back again and lowering the prices so the Basics range has more budget prices  not just only a small bit cheaper than the normal ones!
column9: Sorry you're unhappy Vicky-Louise. We're committed to offering great quality food at fair price. We regularly review prices to make sure we offer value for money and remain competitive. Although we try to keep our pricing as fair as possible sometimes prices will go up as well as down. I will however, make sure your concerns are logged with our buyers. With regards to the multi buys, you can see more here: http://tinyurl.com/hpsh5sb. Liz
